title: Our world in photos : May 10
body_text:
Our world in photos: May 10
HUNTINGTON BEACH — ‘Canary in the mine?’: Volunteer Jason Foo holds a rescued pelican by its beak while treating the bird at the Wetlands and Wildlife Care Center in Huntington Beach, CA, Tuesday, May 7, 2024. Earlier this week, lifeguards spotted a cluster of two dozen sick pelicans on a pier in coastal Newport Beach. Wildlife experts were called in to help with the rescue. It is not immediately clear what is sickening the birds, although some were found enmeshed in fishing lines and hooks. Some wildlife experts noted the pelicans are malnourished, though marine life abounds off the Pacific Coast.
A group called Bird Rescue, which runs two wildlife centers in Northern and Southern California, reported 110 sick pelicans in the past three weeks and noted a similar situation two years ago.
HYDERABAD — The political power of portraits: Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) supporters carry portraits of Prime Minister Narendra Modi as they attend a public rally addressed by Modi in Hyderabad, India, Friday, May 10, 2024. However, Modi’s main challenger was granted bail on Friday. Reuters reports that, on Friday, India’s top court gave temporary bail to Delhi Chief Minister Arvind Kejriwal, who is involved in a graft case. The bail will allow the prominent and staunch critic of Modi to campaign in the ongoing general elections, boosting the opposition alliance. The Supreme Court said Kejriwal would be out on bail until June 1, the last day of the nationwide seven-phase vote.
Modi’s BJP party said it would respect the court order.
ROME — A break to ponder and rest his eyes: Pope Francis gestures as he attends an annual gathering of pro-family organizations at the Auditorium della Conciliazione in Rome, Friday, May 10, 2024. Making his remarks at an annual conference and focusing on the general state of Italy’s birth rate and demographics, the pope said, “Human life is not a problem; it is a gift. The problem is not how many of us there are in the world, but what kind of world we are building.”
Pope Francis also criticized the gun and contraceptive industries, which destroy and prevent life.
BARCELONA — Surge in Catalan power: Spanish Prime Minister Pedro Sánchez applauds the socialist candidate, left, during a campaign rally in Villanova i la Gertru, near Barcelona, Spain, Thursday, May 9, 2024. Some nearly 6 million Catalans are called to cast ballots in regional elections on Sunday that will surely have reverberations in Spain’s national politics. The election will also be a barometer of how well Spain has moved past Catalonia’s attempt to secede from Spain several years ago. Sánchez, who has been President of the Government of Spain since June 2018, is General Secretary of the Spanish Socialist Workers’ Party. Socialist candidate Salvador Illa is a former central government health minister who now leads the Catalan branch of Spain’s ruling socialist party.
Illa is ahead in the polls compared to two opponents, both secessionist. One of these is Carles Puigdemont, Catalonia’s former leader and now a political fugitive.
FLORIDA — Looking into police encounter, another tragic loss: Chantemekki Fortson, mother of Roger Fortson, a U.S. Air Force senior airman, holds a photo of her son during a news conference with attorney Ben Crump, Thursday, May 9, 2024, in Fort Walton Beach, FL. Fortson was shot and killed by police in his apartment on May 3, 2024, after they broke into the wrong unit while responding to a domestic disturbance in the residential complex. Fortson was a U.S. Air Force Senior Airman for whom Air Force service was a lifelong dream. He had earned an Air Medal with combat device, which is typically awarded after 20 flights in a combat zone or for conspicuous valor or achievement on a single mission.
Civil rights attorney Ben Crump has gotten involved in the case, debunking the police’s claim of acting in “self-defense,” reports the Associated Press. Emphasizing the deputy’s error of having entered the wrong apartment, Crump called the shooting unjustified.
JAKARTA — Seeking gold in the garbage: A ragpicker looks for recyclable items in a pile of garbage at a landfill in Depok on the outskirts of Jakarta, Indonesia. Friday, May 10, 2024. Depok for many years has had only one landfill, which is filled beyond capacity. However, the Indonesian government has also worked at putting an end to creating any new landfills so that the nation can better combat climate change, according to Antara, an Indonesian news agency. The National Waste Management Information System estimates that Indonesia produced around 68.5 million tons of waste in 2022, with about 18.5% of it being plastic waste.
The archipelago nation’s Environment and Forestry Ministry has inaugurated the Clean Indonesia 2025 Program, based on Presidential Regulation Number 97 of 2017 that governs national policies and strategies for managing household and household-type waste.
PARIS — ‘I’ve got biceps, I can do a hip check, maybe I should play football …’: Taylor Swift performs at the Paris Le Defense Arena as a part of her Eras Tour concert in Paris, Thursday, May 9, 2024. The all-stadium tour, which kicked off on March 17, 2023, in Glendale, Arizona, consists of 152 conceptually organized concerts that are taking the American singer/songwriter across five continents. The tour concludes in Vancouver, British Columbia on Dec. 8.
The Eras Tour, which covers all styles of music from her 10 studio albums, is said to have become the first tour to surpass $1 billion in revenue, making it the all-time highest-grossing.
SWEDEN — Best thing about Eurovision — the dancers: Nutsa Buzaladze of Georgia performs the song Firefighter during the second semi-final at the Eurovision Song Contest in Malmo, Sweden, Thursday, May 9, 2024. The Eurovision Song Contest has its origins from almost 70 years ago as a technical experiment. The first Eurovision Song Contest was held on May 24, 1956, with seven nations competing: the Netherlands, Switzerland, Belgium, Germany, France, Luxembourg and Italy, according to the contest’s website.
Charlotte Perrelli, Carola and Conchita Wurst are set to perform an homage to ABBA at the Eurovision Song Contest Grand Final on Saturday night. This year marks the 50th anniversary of the Swedish band ABBA’s earning Sweden its very first victory at the Eurovision Song Contest with the smash-hit schlager banger Waterloo.
CALIFORNIA — Campaigning on public money — his prerogative, his duty: President Joe Biden waves as he arrives on Air Force One at Moffett Field, Thursday, May 9, 2024, in Mountain View, CA. His visit, part of a fundraising tour in California and Washington, also includes benefits that wealthy donors will be hosting, with ticket tier pricing that ranges from $6.6K to $100K, according to the New York Times. Among the hosts are senior staff with Amazon and Microsoft.
President Biden’s team is working to underscore a financial advantage over GOP frontrunner Donald Trump, who has had to spend more time lately in courtrooms than on the campaign trail.
MONTREAL — When hockey players collide at the wall … hard to tell who did what to whom: Boston’s Sidney Morin, left, is upended by Montreal’s Melodie Daoust (25) during the second period of Game 1 of a PWHL hockey playoff series Thursday, May 9, 2024, in Montreal. Boston scored a 2-1 win over Montreal in Game 1 of a Professional Women’s Hockey League semifinal.
Game 2 in the series takes place Saturday in Laval. The series’ winner will play either Toronto or Minnesota in a best-of-five final for the Walter Cup. Toronto leads the other semifinal set, 1-0.
MARSEILLE — It’s finally here, all the way from Greece: Torchbearer Didier Drogba of France holds the torch to light the cauldron at the Velodrome stadium in Marseille, southern France, Thursday, May 9, 2024. Torchbearers are to carry the Olympic flame through the streets of France’s southern port city of Marseille one day after it arrived on a majestic three-mast ship for the welcoming ceremony on July 26. The flame will travel to the Lascaux caves, the Alésia archaeological site, the medieval city of Carcassonne, the Palace of Versailles, and many other sites.
The Olympic flame will also light up many of France’s architectural masterpieces and places of remembrance, such as the Verdun Memorial and the D-Day Landing Beaches.
GERMANY — ‘Close your eyes and use the force, you’ll find the ball …’: Leverkusen’s Edmond Tapsoba, left, and Roma’s Lorenzo Pellegrini jump for the ball during the Europa League second leg semi-final soccer match between Leverkusen and Roma at the BayArena in Leverkusen, Germany, Thursday, May 9, 2024. Leverkusen and Roma finished the game on a 2-2 draw, meaning neither team lost, enabling Leverkusen to maintain its unbeaten record. Advancing 4-2 on aggregate, Leverkusen will face another Italian team on May 22 in Dublin. That team — Atalanta — beat Marseille 3-0 to advance 4-1 on aggregate.
Aggregate wins refer to a team’s scores from a series of matches being added together.
QUEENS — Clean-shaven for court: Harvey Weinstein appears in Queens criminal court with his attorneys, Diana Fabi Samson, left, and John Esposito, Thursday, May 9, 2024, in New York. Harvey Weinstein returned to court in New York City as authorities consider an extradition request from California to serve his sentence for a 2022 rape conviction. The 16-year sentence Weinstein received for raping a woman at a Los Angeles film festival in 2013 had been on ice while he served time in New York.
As of Thursday, May 9, Weinstein was to remain in New York as details over the extradition request are worked out.
